children.title: death
children.comment: Death in its various aspects is seen by Scripture as the opposite of God-given life.

children.title: death, natural
children.comment: The end of life in the present world.

children.title: Death is natural to humanity as part of the created world
Death is a result of Adam's sin

primaryrefs.comment: There is a tension between this text and those which suggest that death is a natural aspect of being human. Some suggest that the death referred to here is spiritual rather than physical.

children.title: Death comes to all kinds of people
Only two people did not die

primaryrefs.comment: Enoch and Elijah died in the sense that their bodies were transformed from being suited to earthly life to life in heaven. They anticipated the death of Jesus Christ, whose body was not corrupted but transformed, and the transition to the new world of those who are alive when Jesus Christ comes again.

The idea of reincarnation, that after death people repeatedly return to this life in a lower or higher form, is incompatible with death being once for all and an entrance into heaven or hell after the judgment.

children.title: Death is an aspect of human frailty
Death occurs when God determines it
The prospect of death affects human attitudes and values
The expectation of death is an incentive to serve God
The expectation of death is an incentive to hold material blessings lightly
Death is sometimes desired to escape problems
Death was defeated by Jesus Christ
There is no death in heaven
death, of believers
children.comment: Believers in Jesus Christ will depart from this present life to the joy of God's presence.

children.title: Death is a normal experience for believers
Because of the prospect of heaven
Because it brings relief from trouble and problems
At death believers are with Christ

primaryrefs.comment: The second death is the final banishment of unbelievers from God's presence.

children.title: They have the prospect of a new order of things
Death is to be reversed in resurrection
children.precomment: Though some of the above passages suggest that eternal life in Jesus Christ's presence is experienced immediately at death, others such as the following link these blessings with resurrection at the final coming of Jesus Christ:

children.title: The death of believers is likened to sleep

primaryrefs.comment: Sleep does not imply lack of consciousness but rather rest, renewing and awaking. In the NT it is only used of believers.
Abraham's side suggests a welcome to a place of peace and protection.

children.title: Death and the recognition of others

primaryrefs.comment: ``caught up together'' implies recognition.

seealsos.comment: ``gathered to his people'' (literally ``to his father's kin'') is a common OT expression and implies continued existence together

children.title: Believers can face death without fear
They die in relationship with God
They receive comfort in facing death
In death they can glorify God
In this believers are to be envied
Believers often hated the idea of death
Martyred believers are specially honoured in Scripture
death, of unbelievers
children.comment: The departure from the present life of unrepentant people to await final banishment from God.

children.title: The premature death of unbelievers is the consequence of sin

primaryrefs.comment: OT writers, for whom God's blessing on the righteous occurs mostly in the present life, often saw early or sudden death as divine judgment on the wicked.

children.title: Aspects of the death of unbelievers
God has no pleasure in their death
Descriptions of the death of unbelievers
The consequences of the death of unbelievers
The intermediate state of awaiting judgment
The challenge of the death of unbelievers
The only escape is through Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Death for believers is swallowed up in life, so that they are never personally aware of the pain and sting of death (compare Jn 11:26).

children.title: death, spiritual
children.comment: A condition in this life of alienation from God because of sin. It leads ultimately to the ``second death'', the permanent separation of unbelievers from God.

children.title: Spiritual death means alienation from God in this life
Spiritual death is a result of Adam's sin
A mind controlled by the sinful nature
Acting in ways that lead to death
Spiritual death leads ultimately to the ``second death''
A church may be spiritually dead
Deliverance from spiritual death is only through Jesus Christ

children.comment: The end of life in the present world.

Death is a result of Adam's sin

The idea of reincarnation, that after death people repeatedly return to this life in a lower or higher form, is incompatible with death being once for all and an entrance into heaven or hell after the judgment.

cschildren.title: Dead bodies were to be treated with respect
Unburied dead bodies were a sign of God's curse upon Israel
Contact with dead bodies

children.title: The high priest was not to touch a dead body
Contact with a dead body made a person unclean
Jesus Christ was willing to touch a dead body
The reluctance to approach dead bodies because of the smell
grave, the
children.comment: An OT synonym for death, the natural, inevitable human destiny, though not without hope for the righteous.

cschildren.title: The grave as a place of burial
The grave representing natural death
The grave as judgment
The grave represented only hopelessness and oblivion before Jesus Christ's resurrection
The OT hope of redemption from the grave anticipated the gospel message

children.title: tombs
children.comment: Graves or burial places, often cut out of rock. People were usually buried in family tombs and kings were often buried in royal tombs.

cschildren.title: Tombs cut out of rock
Caves used as tombs
Tombs sealed with a stone
Burial in a family tomb
Royal tombs
Tombs in gardens
Contact with a tomb rendered a person ritually unclean
Figurative use of tombs

children.title: last things
children.comment: The doctrine of the last things (``eschatology'') includes the subjects of death, the second coming of Jesus Christ, the resurrection of the dead, the last judgment, heaven and hell.

cschildren.title: Death

children.title: The timing of natural death is beyond human control
Death is not to be feared by the believer
For believers, death is likened to falling asleep
At the second coming, believers still living on earth will not experience death
Death is the penalty for unforgiven sin

cschildren.title: The second coming of Jesus Christ

children.title: The timing of the second coming is known only to God the Father
God's purpose at the second coming is to gather his people together, to reward the faithful and judge the wicked
The right attitude towards the second coming

cschildren.title: The resurrection of the dead

children.title: Believers in Jesus Christ will be raised to eternal life
Believers will be given resurrection bodies

cschildren.title: The last judgment

children.title: Judgment is entrusted to Jesus Christ
Those who have not responded to Christ will be condemned
Believers will not be judged for sin
Believers will be judged on how they have lived their Christian lives

cschildren.title: Heaven

children.title: God's throne is in heaven where he is continuously worshipped
God's will is perfectly served in heaven
At Jesus Christ's second coming, a new heaven and earth will replace the old
The redeemed will enjoy life in the presence of God in the new heaven
All life in heaven is sustained by God

cschildren.title: Hell

children.title: Hell is the destiny of human beings who reject God

primaryrefs.comment: Hell was originally meant for the punishment of the devil and his angels.

children.title: Those in hell are finally separated from God
Hell is a place of fire, darkness and weeping
Jesus Christ himself frequently warned about the dangers of hell

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ is using Eastern hyperbole, not intended literally, to stress importance

children.title: after-life
children.comment: Although the OT generally portrays this as a vague and shadowy existence, often associated with judgment, there are hints of the idea of resurrection to a fuller life which are developed in the NT. The NT points to judgment beyond death and to the believers' hope in resurrection, to a more complete enjoyment of God's presence and his blessings and to the promise of a new heaven and earth.

cschildren.title: The after-life in the OT

children.title: The grave as a place of silence
The grave as a place of darkness
The grave as a place of no return
The grave as a place of judgment
The grave offers peace to the righteous

cschildren.title: The after-life and God's judgment

children.title: There will be salvation for believers
There will be separation from God for unbelievers

cschildren.title: The believing dead are already with Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Believers, with Jesus Christ in spirit, await their final resurrection which will take place when he returns.

cschildren.title: The after-life and believers' hope of resurrection

children.title: The bodily resurrection of Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: The future consummation of the believers' enjoyment of God

primaryrefs.comment: The final consummation will bring God's promises to and purposes for his people to fulfilment

children.title: The Holy Spirit as a guarantee
antichrist, the
children.comment: One who is directly and implacably opposed to Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: The antichrist will deny fundamental truths about Jesus Christ
Th antichrist as a self-appointed rival to God
The coming of the antichrist is a sign of the ``last days''
The final defeat of the antichrist is assured

children.title: eternity
children.comment: In Scripture eternity is not an abstraction but limitless time, over which God is totally sovereign.

children.title: eternity, nature of
children.comment: God alone possesses lasting time, in contrast to the fleeting time of the human race.

children.title: The name of God and eternity

seealsos.comment: Wisdom (personified) is speaking here.

children.title: eternity, and God
children.comment: Whether one considers the past or the future, God alone is discovered to be permanent and lasting.

children.title: God's being, his wisdom and his word are eternal
God's word has always expressed his nature
God's purpose to bless is eternal
Some aspects of the created order are eternal
eternity, nature of
children.comment: God alone possesses lasting time, in contrast to the fleeting time of the human race.

children.title: The name of God and eternity

seealsos.comment: Wisdom (personified) is speaking here.

children.title: eternity, and God
children.comment: Whether one considers the past or the future, God alone is discovered to be permanent and lasting.

children.title: God's being, his wisdom and his word are eternal
God's word has always expressed his nature
God's purpose to bless is eternal
Some aspects of the created order are eternal
footstool
children.comment: Used mostly symbolically to refer to God's supreme authority over his creation. It is used especially to refer to his final victory over all those who oppose him.

cschildren.title: The footstool as a rest for the feet
The footstool used symbolically

children.title: God's footstool as a symbol for the ark and the temple
God's footstool as a symbol for the earth

primaryrefs.comment: God cannot be confined to any man-made temple.

children.title: Defeated enemies can be regarded as a footstool
Jesus Christ will make all God's enemies his footstool

primaryrefs.comment: This passage affirms Jesus Christ's supremacy over the angels.

children.title: Jesus Christ will complete his victory when he returns
future, the
children.comment: God's promises about the future are certain because it is under God's control. Christians should live on the basis that these promises, which focus on the return of Jesus Christ, will be fulfilled.

cschildren.title: God controls the future
The future is unknown to human beings
There is a future hope for believers

children.title: It is based on God's promise
Future blessings are superior to present experiences

cschildren.title: Key aspects of future hope

children.title: The devil and evil will be destroyed
God's kingdom will be fully established

cschildren.title: Believers' responsibility towards future generations

primaryrefs.comment: The twelve stones taken from the bed of the river Jordan is one of several instances where God's people are told to preserve memorials of present blessings for the sake of future generations.

cschildren.title: Proper attitudes towards the future

children.title: Avoiding occult predictions and false prophecies
immortality
children.comment: The quality of enduring into eternity, which Scripture insists belongs to God alone. However, God bestows the gift of eternal life and immortality upon those who believe and trust in him.

children.title: immortality, in OT
children.comment: The OT stresses that God alone is immortal and indicates that this gift may be granted to human beings under certain conditions.

children.title: Immortality is an attribute of God
God is everlasting in his character and actions

primaryrefs.comment: The way in which Scripture emphasises the character of God in these contexts shows that immortality is about a quality of being as well as about infinite duration.

secondaryrefs.comment: the LORD as the everlasting light

children.title: Immortality is conditionally offered to human beings

seealsos.comment: The most specific OT reference to immortality. Note that while resurrection to judgment is for all, immortality is only for the righteous (Pr 12:28).

children.title: Enoch and Elijah: two special cases
immortality, in NT
children.comment: In the NT, immortal life is offered to human beings through Jesus Christ and guaranteed by the Holy Spirit. It is closely associated with eternal life and resurrection, but is seen more as a quality of being rather than in terms of unlimited extent.

children.title: Immortality is an attribute of God
Immortality is offered to human beings through Jesus Christ
Immortality is guaranteed by the Holy Spirit
The association of immortality with eternal life
The association of immortality with resurrection
Immortality implied by Jesus Christ's transfiguration

secondaryrefs.comment: the presence of Moses and Elijah

children.title: Immortality as a quality of being
It is inseparable from God's other characteristics
It is inseparable from humanity's final state of existence

children.comment: The OT stresses that God alone is immortal and indicates that this gift may be granted to human beings under certain conditions.

God is everlasting in his character and actions

last days
children.comment: The final epoch of history which is marked by the coming of the Messiah and the establishment of God's kingdom. In the NT it is portrayed as the period between Jesus Christ's first coming and the consummation of all things at his return, and is marked by godlessness and the persecution of God's people.

cschildren.title: OT expectation of the last days
Jesus Christ's coming introduces the last days
Revelation in the last days
Redemption in the last days
Features of the last days
Jesus Christ's return brings the last days to a close

children.title: It ushers in a new era
It is identified with the day of the LORD

cschildren.title: Living in the last days

primaryrefs.comment: Between Jesus Christ's comings, believers have a foretaste of the age to come.

children.title: Messianic age
children.comment: In the OT, writers look forward to the era that will be inaugurated by God's decisive intervention in human history, in order to establish his eternal kingdom under the Messiah. The Messianic age is characterised by righteousness, justice and peace, by the outpouring of the Holy Spirit and by the restoration and renewal of God's people and of creation. In the NT, the idea appears in a developed form as the ``kingdom of God'', inaugurated by the first coming of Jesus Christ and to be consummated at his return.

cschildren.title: The victory of God's kingdom foreseen

primaryrefs.comment: This psalm came to be applied to the Messiah.

seealsos.comment: This psalm was also applied to the Messiah in the OT times

cschildren.title: Restoration in the Messianic age

children.title: Restoration and renewal of God's people

cschildren.title: Characteristics of the Messianic age

children.title: The outpouring of the Holy Spirit

cschildren.title: The kingdom of God in the NT

children.title: Inaugurated at Jesus Christ's first coming
Includes the restoration of all things
Messianic banquet
children.comment: A symbolic portrayal of the blessings of the age to come in which those chosen by God share in a rich feast with the Messiah. In the NT this is often pictured as a marriage supper with Jesus Christ as the groom and the church as both bride and invited guests. The feast, which will take place after the consummation of God's kingdom, is prefigured in the Lord's Supper.

cschildren.title: The Messianic banquet promised
The significance of banqueting

children.title: As a sign of spiritual blessing
As a sign of spiritual satisfaction
As a sign of fellowship with God

seealsos.comment: This may have been a covenant meal to seal the covenant between God and Israel

cschildren.title: The Messianic banquet as a wedding feast
The anticipation of the Messianic banquet

children.title: It is prefigured in the Lord's Supper

primaryrefs.comment: The Messianic banquet is here associated with the Passover meal which Jesus Christ shared with his disciples

children.title: millennium
children.comment: The period of 1,000 years referred to in Revelation chapter 20, during which Satan is bound and believers reign with Jesus Christ. This millennium is understood in different ways: as a period of unparalleled peace and prosperity for the church and the gospel at the end of this age, after which Christ will return (postmillennialism); as the time following Christ's return when he will reign on earth (premillennialism); as a symbolic reference to the period between Christ's first and second comings (amillennialism).

cschildren.title: Characteristics of the millennium

primaryrefs.comment: ``the Abyss'' is the subterranean place of confinement for Satan and evil spirits.

children.title: Martyred believers are raised to reign with Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Those who have suffered for the gospel receive their promised reward.

cschildren.title: The millennium will be a golden age on earth

primaryrefs.comment: The OT looks forward to a period of universal peace and prosperity on earth. Both pre- and postmillennialists see this as a reference to Jesus Christ's future earthly reign.

cschildren.title: The premillennial interpretation

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's return. Premillennialists understand the events of Revelation chapter 19 to precede those of Revelation chapter 20
a ``first resurrection'' of believers to share Jesus Christ's reign over the earth
the general resurrection of all people to face God's judgment

primaryrefs.comment: This passage allows the idea of a gap between the resurrection of believers and the eternal age.

children.title: Believers will reign with Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Premillennialists take this to refer to an earthly reign.

children.title: Difficulties with premillennialism
children.precomment: Scriptures that depict a single resurrection of both the righteous and the wicked:

children.precomment: As a reference to the soul entering heaven after death:

children.title: new heavens and new earth
children.comment: A way of referring to the new creation that will come about at the end of time. The theme of the restoration and re-creation of the world is a central aspect of the Christian hope.

cschildren.title: The new heavens and new earth will replace the old
The nature of the new heavens and new earth

children.title: The effects of the fall will be reversed
restoration
children.comment: The returning of something or someone to their original state. Through the redeeming work of Jesus Christ, both humanity and creation will eventually be restored.

cschildren.title: Restoration of human beings through the ministry of Jesus Christ
The restoration of creation
The restoration of Israel
Restoration in everyday life

children.title: signs of the times
children.comment: Portents marking significant historical events. In Scripture the phrase refers principally to signs indicating the coming of the Messiah and the kingdom of God (both in the ministry of Jesus Christ and at the end of time).

cschildren.title: Signs of the times signifying the future deliverance of Judah

secondaryrefs.comment: The fruitfulness of the earth is to be a sign to Hezekiah that there will be a fruitful remnant of Judah.

cschildren.title: Signs of the times in the life of Jesus Christ

children.title: The virgin birth of Jesus Christ
The Jews failed to perceive the signs of the times accompanying Jesus Christ's coming

cschildren.title: Signs of the times at the end of the age

children.title: It is impossible to predict the date of Jesus Christ's return from the signs of the times

cschildren.title: Signs of the times signifying judgment

seealsos.comment: The fall of Jerusalem is itself a sign of the judgment of all people at the end of time.

cschildren.title: Interpreting the signs of the times

children.title: judgment, God's
children.comment: God judges the world by identifying and condemning sin and by vindicating and rewarding the righteous. God exercises temporal judgment on the world and on his people; final judgment will take place when Jesus Christ returns.

cschildren.title: The nature of God's judgment
The purpose of God's judgment

children.title: To bring salvation to his people

primaryrefs.comment: Temporal judgments may turn people to God and so save them from eternal judgment.

cschildren.title: God's judgment may be delayed
Examples of God's judgment

seealsos.comment: Jehoram
Belshazzar
Jezebel, the false prophetess

cschildren.title: God's judgment on Israel

secondaryrefs.comment: The cycle of sin, defeat and deliverance is repeated several times in Judges

cschildren.title: God's final judgment on the whole earth

children.title: day of the LORD
children.comment: The occasion of God's final intervention in human affairs to punish sin, restore the faithful of his people and establish his rule over the nations. It is linked with the Messianic hope and will be fulfilled at Jesus Christ's return. This future consummation is anticipated in historical acts of judgment and, although its time is unknown, it will be heralded and accompanied by signs and by great upheavals in nature.

cschildren.title: The day of the LORD as a day of judgment

seealsos.comment: God's judgment on Babylon
God's judgment on Edom

cschildren.title: The day of the LORD as a day of hope

children.title: A day of restoration for God's people
God will complete his saving work

primaryrefs.comment: The ``day of Christ Jesus'' is the NT equivalent to the ``day of the LORD'' which refers to Jesus Christ's second coming.

cschildren.title: The siege and deliverance of Jerusalem on the day of the LORD

children.title: The LORD will fight for Jerusalem

cschildren.title: The establishment of God's kingdom on the day of the LORD

children.title: God's kingdom will be universal and everlasting
God will be the object of universal worship
God's rule will be centred on a restored Jerusalem

cschildren.title: The fulfilment of Messianic hope on the day of the LORD
Being prepared for the day of the Lord

children.title: The need to be ready for the day
Signs heralding the day may be discerned

cschildren.title: The day of the Lord will be accompanied by signs and great upheavals in nature
Historical events anticipate the day of the LORD

secondaryrefs.comment: Israel devastated by a locust swarm
Israel defeated and exiled by Assyria

children.title: Return from exile foreshadows final restoration
judgment seat
children.comment: The platform or throne from which kings and officials administer justice. God presently exercises judgment from his heavenly throne, symbolised in the OT by the ark of the covenant, and will one day bring all peoples before his judgment seat to give account of their lives and to receive their due reward.

cschildren.title: Examples of earthly seats of judgment
God's judgment seat

children.title: The ark as a symbol of God's throne

primaryrefs.comment: God's future judgment is exercised through Jesus Christ

children.title: Believers will share Jesus Christ's judgment throne
last judgment
children.comment: God's judgment of all people at the end of the age. This has been entrusted to Jesus Christ who, at his return, will reward the righteous and punish the unrighteous. Judgment will be on the basis of deeds, the response to God's revelation and faith in Jesus Christ. Believers need not fear the last judgment, but should live godly lives in anticipation of it.

cschildren.title: The certainty of last judgment
The time of last judgment

children.title: It was anticipated in the cross

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ is speaking about his approaching death.

children.title: It will take place at the end of the age
It will take place at Jesus Christ's return

cschildren.title: Last judgment is the prerogative of God

children.title: God entrusts judgment to Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: The result of last judgment
The basis of God's last judgment

seealsos.comment: Those towns and cities which have rejected the revelation that Christ brings will face final judgment and condemnation

children.title: It is according to attitude to Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: The only basis for salvation is faith in Jesus Christ.

seealsos.comment: Those towns which reject Jesus Christ's messengers will face judgment
Those who disown Jesus Christ will be disowned by him

cschildren.title: The fairness of God's last judgment
Believers and last judgment

children.title: Believers should live in the light of final judgment

secondaryrefs.comment: building with materials that will last

children.title: woe
children.comment: An exclamation of judgment upon God's enemies, or of misfortune on oneself, or, in the ministry of Jesus Christ, of sadness over those who fail to recognise the true misery of their condition.

cschildren.title: Woe as an exclamation of judgment on others

primaryrefs.comment: Probably referring to Assyria.

children.title: Woe to careless leaders of God's people
Woe to those who are complacent in their prosperity or religion
Woe to those who neglect social justice

cschildren.title: Woe as an exclamation of misfortune on oneself

children.title: Woe as a consequence of circumstances or events

primaryrefs.comment: Jeremiah is describing the pain he feels at the impending destruction of his nation.

children.title: Woe as a consequence of one's own sin
Woe as a consequence of God's call on one's life

cschildren.title: Woe as an exclamation of sadness over others

children.title: Woe to those who do not recognise their own needs
Woe to those whose religion blinds themselves and misleads others
Woe to those who cause others to sin
Woe to those on whom judgment is coming
Woe to the one who betrays the Son of Man
Woe to those who experience the signs of the end of the age

primaryrefs.comment: The word translated ``how dreadful'' is the same word that elsewhere is translated ``woe''.

cschildren.title: Woe may give way to forgiveness, comfort and deliverance

seealsos.comment: After the woes of earlier chapters, Isaiah now prophesies the comfort that will come to God's people

children.title: resurrection
children.comment: The raising of Jesus Christ from the dead by God after his suffering and death on the cross. Historical evidence for his resurrection includes the empty tomb and the appearance of the risen Christ to the disciples. It has significance both in relation to the identity of Jesus Christ and the future hope of believers.

children.title: resurrection, of Jesus Christ
children.comment: The resurrection of Jesus Christ is of central importance to the NT. It affirms the divinity of Jesus Christ, marks the words and deeds of his ministry with God's seal of approval and opens the way to the future resurrection of believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's resurrection was foreshadowed in the OT
Jesus Christ's resurrection was anticipated by the raising of the dead

primaryrefs.comment: None of the OT or NT miracles are true resurrections. Those raised resumed life as before, their bodies unchanged. Resurrection for Jesus Christ and therefore for his people means a changed body and permanent life in glory. This is the ``better resurrection''.

children.title: In the miracles of Jesus Christ
The sequence of events in Jesus Christ's resurrection
It was preceded by suffering and death
It took place on the first day of the week
The disciples were reluctant to believe it
The disciples saw the evidence and were ultimately convinced
The risen Christ appeared to many people

secondaryrefs.comment: to two on the Emmaus road

children.title: The resurrection was followed by Jesus Christ's entry into glory
Jesus Christ's resurrection body was spiritual but not ghostly
resurrection, significance of Jesus Christ's
children.comment: Jesus Christ's resurrection represents a demonstration of the power of God, the confirmation of the divinity of Jesus Christ and the grounds of hope for Christian believers.

children.title: Jesus Christ's resurrection was a demonstration of God's power
The power of God the Father
The power of the Holy Spirit
The resurrection confirmed Jesus Christ as the Son of God

primaryrefs.comment: John calls Jesus Christ's miracles ``signs'' (see also Jn 2:11; 6:2) and his resurrection is the climax, confirming his identity beyond all doubt

children.title: The centrality of the resurrection of Jesus Christ
As the basis of believers' justification
As the basis of Christian hope
As the basis of believers' resurrection

primaryrefs.comment: The Law of Moses (Ex 23:16) provided for an offering of the firstfruits of crops to God. The firstfruits were the guarantee of the full harvest to come. The NT sees the resurrection of Jesus Christ as the firstfruits of the full ingathering of all God's people when Jesus Christ comes again.

children.title: resurrection, spiritual
children.comment: The gospel brings new life to men and women, who lived in death and darkness until they came to faith. The NT emphasis upon ``being made alive in Christ'' is closely linked to the resurrection of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Crossing over from death to life
Believers continue to live by the power of the risen Christ
Results of being made alive in Christ
resurrection, of the dead
children.comment: Scripture speaks of a general resurrection of all people at the end of time, which will be followed by judgment.

children.title: The resurrection of the dead predicted
The resurrection of the dead will occur at Jesus Christ's return
The resurrection of the dead includes both the righteous and wicked
Attitudes to the resurrection of the dead
resurrection, of believers
children.comment: The future event of finally being raised to glory with Jesus Christ. Believers may rest assured that, on account of their faith, they will share in the resurrection and glory of Christ and be with him for ever.

children.title: The nature of the resurrection of believers
Being completely united to Jesus Christ
It leads to becoming like Jesus Christ
The resurrection as the future hope of believers

primaryrefs.comment: In the NT the death of believers is often likened to sleep.

children.title: The resurrection as an incentive to godliness and perseverance
The resurrection as an incentive to endurance of suffering
resurrection, of Jesus Christ

The resurrection as an incentive to endurance of suffering
heaven
children.comment: God's habitation where he is worshipped and served by angels. Solely on account of the sacrifice of Jesus Christ on the cross, believers will inherit a place in heaven and there for ever enjoy perfect fellowship with God in his worship and service.

children.title: heaven, nature of
children.comment: Scripture refers to heaven as God's habitation but also uses the term as an alternative for God himself.

children.title: It is the place where he dwells
It is insufficient as God's dwelling-place
Heaven as the place of God's throne
Heaven as an alternative term for God

seealsos.comment: Matthew is writing especially for Jews who, out of reverence, tried to avoid using the word ``God''. Mk 4:11 and Lk 8:10 prefer ``kingdom of God''

children.title: Heaven and the sovereignty of God
Heaven is the place of God's rule
God's voice from heaven speaks with divine authority
At the baptism of Jesus Christ
Prayer addressed to God in heaven
The association of oaths with heaven
The place of Jesus Christ in heaven
His ascension into heaven after his resurrection
His place is now with God the Father
His second coming will be from heaven
The new heaven completely replaces the old
The new Jerusalem is divinely created in heaven
Fulness of life in heaven is wholly sustained by God
heaven, worship and service in
children.comment: All in heaven engage continuously in the worship of God, while they perfectly carry out his will.

children.title: The multitude in heaven and the twenty-four elders
Jesus Christ is worshipped in heaven
God's will is perfectly done in heaven
The redeemed will reign with Jesus Christ and share his authority
They serve by delivering believers in trouble
heaven, inheritance of
children.comment: Heaven is the secure inheritance, of priceless value, awaiting the redeemed. There, faithful service will be rewarded and the redeemed will be given resurrection bodies for service in the heavenly realm.

children.title: Believers inherit the kingdom of heaven
The value of their inheritance is beyond human calculation
As those adopted into God's family they are heirs of God and Christ
The nature of the heavenly inheritance
It is a response to faith and love
The heavenly treasure is to be sought
Service will be rewarded in heaven
The prospect of heavenly rewards should be a spur to present service
Endurance for Jesus Christ's sake will be specially rewarded
Rewards for service include crowns signifying position and authority
The redeemed will share Jesus Christ's position in glory
The resurrection body as a heavenly inheritance
heaven, as community of the redeemed
children.comment: The community of the redeemed in heaven will represent all peoples and languages. They will owe this solely to the sacrifice of Jesus Christ. They will share in the divine life in perfect fellowship with God, free for ever from suffering and death.

children.title: Divine preparations made for believers in heaven
The redeemed in heaven come from all peoples
The redeemed owe their place in heaven solely to Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Washing one's robes in the blood of the Lamb symbolises cleansing through the sacrifice of Jesus Christ.

children.title: The redeemed are identified with Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ acknowledges the redeemed as his own
Believers possess the family likeness to Jesus Christ
Believers on earth at the second coming will be taken up to heaven

seealsos.comment: Believers living on earth when Jesus Christ returns will not experience death, but be taken straight to heaven.

children.title: Conditions in heaven for the redeemed
Perpetual and perfect fellowship with the Lord
Joy in the immediate presence of God
There will no longer be any need for the marriage relationship
Heaven is filled with the light of God's glory
Believers will share Jesus Christ's glory
Divine glory will banish the memory of earthly troubles
There will be no more death or suffering in heaven
Believers are citizens of the heavenly Jerusalem
Their names are enrolled as citizens of heaven
heaven, nature of
children.comment: Scripture refers to heaven as God's habitation but also uses the term as an alternative for God himself.

children.title: It is the place where he dwells

Their names are enrolled as citizens of heaven
book of life
children.comment: Book in which the names of the living were recorded and from which their names were removed at death. From the time of the exodus onwards, Scripture contains references to God's book of life. It is to contain only the names of the righteous and is to be opened on the day of judgment.

cschildren.title: The privilege of having one's name in the book of life
The unrighteous are excluded from the book of life
Other references to such a book
The destination of the righteous after death

primaryrefs.comment: This Persian term originally described a park or pleasure garden. It was used by the Jews of the Garden of Eden, and of the future blessedness of the saints.

children.title: hell
children.comment: A term used in English translations of the Bible to represent the Hebrew word ``Sheol'' (the place of the departed) and the Greek word ``Gehenna'', which came to refer to the place of punishment for the wicked after death. The Valley of Hinnom (Hebrew ``Ge Hinnom'', from which ``Gehenna'' is derived) on the south side of Jerusalem became a symbol of all that is hateful to God, on account of its use for human sacrifice.

children.title: hell, as a place of punishment
children.comment: The place of eternal punishment in fire and darkness intended for Satan and his angels, but also for human beings who choose to reject God.

children.title: Hell was originally created for the devil and his angels
Hell is a consequence of rejecting God

seealsos.comment: Fire is often referred to in the OT as a symbol of divine judgment

children.title: Jesus Christ possesses authority over hell

primaryrefs.comment: The Greek word ``Hades'' often simply means ``death''. However, at points it implies the experience of punishment after death.

children.title: The Valley of Hinnom as a figure of hell
The Valley of Hinnom as a geographical feature
The Valley of Hinnom as a place of child sacrifice
The Valley of Hinnom as a place of God's judgment
The Valley of Hinnom as a synonym for hell

primaryrefs.comment: The word used for ``hell'' is ``Gehenna'', from the Hebrew ``Ge Hinnom'', meaning ``the Valley of Hinnom''.

children.title: hell, as an experience
children.comment: The state of final separation from God, and so from all light, love, peace, pleasure and fulfilment.

children.title: The final state of the wicked is one of eternal punishment

primaryrefs.comment: ``eternal punishment'' means the punishment that is part of, and belongs to, the final order of things that follows this present age. This is usually, though not invariably, understood as an unending process of punishment consciously experienced by the wicked.

children.title: hell, as incentive to action
children.comment: The reality of hell should affect the way people live.

children.title: The importance of making the right choice
A personal spiritual life is vital
It is more important than short-term worldly gain
It is not just outward appearance
Religious activity alone is not only valueless but perilous
Believers must maintain their loyalty to God
Temptations to sin must be dealt with drastically
Some attitudes and practices that lead to hell

primaryrefs.comment: Sodom, destroyed by God, was notoriously sinful.
The term ``fool'' implied the despising of another as worthless and godless.

children.title: hell, as a place of punishment
children.comment: The place of eternal punishment in fire and darkness intended for Satan and his angels, but also for human beings who choose to reject God.

children.title: Hell was originally created for the devil and his angels

The term ``fool'' implied the despising of another as worthless and godless.

children.title: Abyss, the
children.comment: Derived from a Greek word meaning ``something which is bottomless'' and often used to refer to a place of despair in which demons are imprisoned.

cschildren.title: The Abyss as a place of despair
The Abyss as the home of demons
The Abyss as a prison

children.title: Hades
children.comment: A term used in the NT to refer to the place in which departed spirits rest, while waiting for judgment.

cschildren.title: Hades is the place where the dead wait for judgment

seealsos.comment: translated ``depths''
translated ``hell''

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ is Lord of Hades

children.title: Sheol
children.comment: A Hebrew term used to refer to the grave, the pit or the tomb. Some older translations have the term incorrectly translated as ``hell''.

cschildren.title: Sheol is the destiny of all
Sheol is often described in terms suggesting a grave
To go to Sheol was regarded as a punishment
There is hope even in Sheol

children.title: hope
children.comment: In Scripture, a confident expectation for the future, describing both the act of hoping and the object hoped for. When grounded in God, hope provides the motivation to live the Christian life even in the face of trouble.

children.title: hope, nature of
children.comment: Hope, in its general sense, is the anticipation of a future outcome. It is a subjective expectation which may be either firmly based or misdirected.

children.title: Hope that an event will take place

seealsos.comment: Felix hoped Paul would offer him a bribe
Paul hoped to visit Rome on his way to Spain
The two disciples share their hopes with Jesus Christ on the Emmaus road

children.title: The malicious hope of the wicked
hope, in God
children.comment: A total grounding of one's confidence and expectation in God's goodness and providential care even in the face of trouble.

children.title: Hope can be placed in Scripture as the word of God
Hope can be placed in God in the face of difficulty or trial
The outcome of hoping in God

seealsos.comment: There is no shame for those who hope in the LORD
The LORD helps and protects those who hope in him
rest
wisdom
restoration
the example of Abraham's hope
eternal life

children.title: hope, as confidence
children.comment: Hope means more than a vague wish that something will happen. It is a sure and confident expectation in God's future faithfulness and presence. The horizon of Christian hope extends beyond death into an eternity prepared by God himself, the reality of which is guaranteed by Jesus Christ.

children.title: God and Jesus Christ are the hope of believers
The hope of resurrection and eternal life

primaryrefs.comment: The Sadducees did not believe in the resurrection whereas the Pharisees did

children.title: The effect of future hope on living now

seealsos.comment: Hope induces a longing for what will be when Jesus Christ returns

children.title: hope, results of its absence
children.comment: An absence of hope leads to a loss of vision, a sense of despondency and ultimately to despair. This contrasts sharply with the Christian hope.

children.title: Feelings produced by a lack of hope
A sense of being abandoned by God
A deep longing for life to end
The outcome of a lack of hope
The choice of trusting in God or futile self-effort
hope, results of
children.comment: Hope gives believers confidence and reassurance in this present life, allowing them to lead effective lives for God. It also reassures them of the reality of eternal life, allowing them to face death with confidence.

children.title: Hope reassures believers in this present life
Hope reassures believers in their faith
Hope encourages believers to look for restoration
Hope leads to more effective Christian living and witness
Hope encourages believers to be bold
Hope equips believers for spiritual warfare
Hope enables believers to face suffering with confidence
Hope enables believers to face the future with confidence
Hope assures believers of an eternal dimension to life
Hope enables believers to face death with confidence
Hope assures believers of their eternal life
Hope enables believers to face the coming wrath with confidence
Hope assures believers of their heavenly inheritance
